Welcome to the tenth eleventh iteration of this thread! Ask your simpler game questions here, and see them answered (usually!)

We use a particular format, so please be sure to number your questions and answers accordingly. Also, please attempt to search the forum before you ask; the answer may have been posted in a previous thread.

Format Example:

(Person with a question) Q1: If the ship moves, and we don't arrive at a planet, what happens to the planets we scanned?

(Person with an answer) A1: Those planets are lost forever, and you have to scan for new ones.

On december 20, 2014
Kyubey

Q2 How many shots does a pilot drone shoot per cycle
2b does Turbo affect this?

A2: only one shot per cycle
A2b: with turbo it is 80% chance for 2 actions and therefore 2 shots

Also note:
- Taking off/landing is another action too. So turbo drone will take off+shoot once on first cycle, then shoot 2 times per cycle
- You can take off, while holding drone. If you stay in space with him, he will shoot from our ship (if he can) or land it (if all enemies are killed or no charges left). So you can use this to take off to kill hunters with quite no ap on your own, if you need too. You cannot use this trick for free taking off - drone will go alone, even if you were holding him
- Drone will shoot hunters just when they arrived. If they came on D2C3 and he was in bay - when NERON announce their arrival, he already took off and attacked them

From my experience pilot drones are great to take down asteroids (so you are not forced to move/spend ap, if you cannot find good planets - nice on ~D10) or to finish small waves of hunters (small part of big wave, that survived you human-pilots). Just don't expect them to deal with 30 hunters in time and they will be very useful.

Q8 - Natamy rifle, 2-4 damage to humans, or 3-5?
On december 24, 2014
[7950824]

A8

2-4 according to the wiki (have not personally wandered around shooting enough humans to test for myself).

However.... it has close to 100% chance to cause at least 1 wound, and can cause 3. Never heard of more than 3 from one shot, but who knows.

Most wounds lower max health.

There are several ways you can cause a full health human to die from a single natamy shot, some happen instantly, the rest happen a few rounds later unless your ship has some excellent medical care going for it, and enough AP floating around to wrap your ship in cotton wool so nothing else can harm it for the rest of your journey.

To me, the number 1 reason to shoot anyone with Natamy is so they die as quickly as possible and do as little as possible before dying (wounds can reduce your 'I will now do this!' options quite effectively).

Oh yeah, and in case my point was too vague.... to me there's only one reason to shoot anyone with a Natamy

[7950824]

A15 followup:

There's only a couple ship conditions that allow humans to win - as I count wins, and as I believe the game creators count wins - in order for humans to win these two conditions must be met:

1) there must be no living mush at the time the game ends,
2) the game must end by Return to Sol or Onwards to Eden.

Anything any mush does to prevent these two conditions from being met when the game ends is a mush win.

So:

Mush can win if they convert a lot of people, or none - conversion actually is not part of their wincon..... and mush could convert half the ship and still lose (rare though that is).

Mush can win by destroying the ship - or allowing it to be destroyed, by control of items, resources, essential skills, or any other means.

Mush can win by finding a way to finish Pilgred and forcing the ship back to sol with at least 1 live mush aboard.

Mush can win by infecting a person or two, 'allowing' humans to catch and kill two mush (do NOT play against your team, but actual plans that include the death of someone if necessary, if it is a reasonable plan that should work and clearly is not surrender or suicide) and allowing the ship to believe there are no mush left, thus 'sneaking' to Sol or Eden by never getting caught.

Mush can win by acting totally human the entire game, and just staying alive and 'one of the probably human people' all game, never doing anything 'mushy' - no spores made, nothing sabotaged, straight pro-human play from selection on. In fact, if you have a mush doing this - game rules actually protect them a bit - you're not allowed to just force mush testing on all or a bunch of the people who you think may be mush but don't have evidence on and face sanction if you are reported for doing so. I call this 'ghosting' to the end (usually ship destruction or all humans dead because the humans know they cannot go back to Sol with a live mush)) - it's not really sneaky, because humans know they have a mush, they just don't know who.



I anticipate some questions about 'What do you do, if you have a ghosting mush, how do you catch them!?!?!'

Hehe.

You force the game to stay in play until you somehow catch them, that's what you do. You don't force the mush test, you force the game to continue.

The game is programmed to do 'random human tests' of a sort, and those get more common as the days pass. Random diseases can happen at cycle changes, creating roomlogs of symptoms or being cured through healing or other means (except going away at cycle change... no roomlog there), well mush don't get those. Does the mush remember to eat so they don't mysteriously not starve? Does the mush appear to get AP from eating?

Dangers get higher later in play. Even if your ship gets down to asphyxiation conditions - if your mush is not acting mushy at all even then, that's a lottery of death that could kill the mush and leave the humans free to then fix Pilgred and scram to Sol with the win. (yep, I've been part of ships that did this, except the mush has always chosen to act out near the end so far - but that's one way to handle it if needed).

While you can't force mush tests, or human tests, on anyone.... allowing rotten food to be on the ship and possibly eaten is legal. Telling all the confirmed 'non-alpha mush' that the bananas in the lab are rotten, ignore them, then waiting to see if those who do eat them get sick (and adding those who do to the list of confirmed 'non-alpha' folks) is legal. There's quite a few 'sneaky' non-forced 'tests' you can legally do, and some of them are so subtle that the mush would not know if it is happening or not if they are not being told about it.

One of the ways to catch that mush is to confirm that everyone else, or almost everyone else cannot be mush - I would personally accept if you can get the list of suspects down to 2, one probably human and one definitely mush but you are not sure which, that you are not randomly killing if you kill one of those two, and if that one is human, kill the other - if the ship is running out of time. But you need to not just randomly start killing or forcibly testing a group of unconfirmed people - that is sanctionable.

[7950824]

There's as many ways to try and win, for both teams, as there are players. Most ways are legal - if there's not a rule against it and you think of it, use it.

For myself when I am mush, I 'let the ship tell me how to kill it' when possible. Over time, ships develop problems and if not fixed, those problems will kill the ship.

You as mush can win that way - the game itself is not just randomly proving humans as human - which humans need to be watching for to use against you, and need a LOT of humans proven if there are a lot of humans alive before you are in danger - but the game is also randomly giving survival tests to the human team. Hunter waves, broken vital things, bad planets found but not good ones, bad luck on expos - there's even more pressure on humans than there is on mush, through the random system in most games (it is random, so randomly you may find a ship where the RNG loves humans and tortures mush - that's fine, it's rare, just do your best if you face that and enjoy knowing that it's rare and you were lucky enough to get to 'enjoy' it).

The humans need to play well and be pretty active to face all the challenges that they will get over time. The ship and its humans will 'tell' you after a while how they'd 'like' to die - they do this by failing to control something that can kill them or the ship. Is the hull getting very low? How about the O2? Morale? Health? Number of Pilots? Number of techs?

You don't have to kill a player with a vital skill. Maybe you can transfer into them instead. Think about everything that will happen when you transfer, what confusion you can cause before or after (and such a thing is often 'all your eggs in one bucket', because you often have revealed yourself once you transfer). But if they have serious morale problems and you transfer into their one source of morale, even if you can't or don't choose to kill anyone, you now control the morale and killing you won't help that problem (make sure they cannot just skip back to sol.... delay as needed, stall, make your plan and choose your timing).

One extremely neat way to convert people - all those once a day things, from spiking to use of fertile and defacer - that all 'resets' when you transfer - it's a limit on the character body, not the player. One ship where I was the only active mush, I had two people with 1 spore each in my dorm (trapper had given them those spores), as well as some other people, a camera.... other skills fertile, transfer, and defacer.

I defaced the room, fertile-made one spore, spiked one of the two with a spore to bring him to 2 spores, transferred to the other player with 1 spore, which reset fertile and defacer (didn't need the second defacer, but did need the fertile), fertile-made that body's spore, spiked the 2 spore person to finish converting him.

Didn't matter the antimush research done (gas and constipaspore among others), didn't matter that I was solo active mush (though my inactive partner actually was useful - sure there are 3 mush now - but which 3? Probably 2 in the defaced dorm, but who else?), without infector I managed to use luck and human decisions to set up a fast and confusion conversion (really helped too that a human entered the dorm that cycle, dirty, and without giving a reason. that human wasn't involved in the transfer or conversion, but was believed to be one of the mush - and wasn't. Legal to kill that human, sure that's 'evidence' so would not be sanctionable.... but the player died human, and added greatly to the confusion - after all, there's not even proof that the conversion happened in that room, it could have been distraction to hide a conversion that happened elsewhere).

So, look at your options. Watch your ship, and remember that until you reveal yourself, you have many, many days unless something weird happens - you have plenty of time to use what the humans do against them, and 'let the humans tell you how they want to lose'. Help them, you're a nice mush after all, and if the humans didn't want to lose that way - they wouldn't have set up the opportunity for you to exploit, now would they?

On december 27, 2014
Kyubey
1pringlemight i ask how you killed the ship? did you mutate?

People told you about diffirent more cunning ways to win, and I'll focus on massacre
http://mush.twinoid.com/theEnd/5898 - check that for example, 2 mushes, both using transfers to humans with proper skills and full ap killed all 14 humans and survived

Your main questions will be:
- What weapons/skills I can use?
- How many humans I will be able to kill?
- Will the ship survive without those humans?

Don't rampage, if you think losing some humans will still leave them a good chance to win! You need to wipe them out, not to annoy them.

First of all remember 3 main groups to focus:
- Teches. Without teches PILGRED repairs are very difficult. They are still possiable if humans have no other problems.
- Pilots. Without pilots it's very difficult to fight the hunters.
- Morale support. While it's possiable to reach D8 without any players with morale-skills (including no MOH on Chun) just on cat+comm link, morale can easily break, when mushes start mass-murdering.

What weapons to use:
- Grenade. Or 2. Ship has one from start, and one BP (BP requires just O2+fuel, so can be always made). Don't expect them to kill anyone, they are very random, but they wound everyone in room badly. Use in room where most of humans are.
- Knife. Good chance to hit, good damage, quite low risk to self-injury, unlimited ammo. It's so much better for mushes then humans, that I prefer to see this thing dismanteled when I'm humans
- If you are not shooter, don't use the blaster. It has just 50% to hit and quite often cause self-injuries on miss, which can ruin everything. Also it's damage is not better then knife.
- Well, if humans made NCC lenses, if they got Old Faithful BP and 4 metal in AB2 was collected you can try that. 12 shoots, 87%, injuries on every shoot, and you can feel like Terminator, annihilating little humans

Now let's see what skills will help you a lot:
- Shooter. Improves blaster a lot, you have 4 points to shoot for free (start rampage just very cycle change to have all 4 points used), descrease chance to self-injury and sometimes you do headshots
- Wrestler. You don't need knife anyone, you just crush humans with fists
- Diplomat. You can activate ceasefire, so no human can do you any harm for 3 cycles (you and your partner can restore up to 6 ap).

Mush skills:
- If you decided to start rampage before humans got Gas and Serum - take Phagocyte. Every spore can be turned into 2ap, it can help a lot
- Transfer. It will allow you to take any body to continue the fun. Good targets to transfer:
a) People with important skills. If they have gold Raluca, who can fix PILGRED in no time you can just switch bodies and they don't have gold-Raluca anymore
b) Humans with good skills for your rampage: Derek for wrestler, Janice for diplomat, anyone who can take shooter
c) Just an idle human- 12ap/12mp for 3ap (extract spore+spike) is a good trade

Q29 I want to play a ship but I'm only being offered one character (Hua) Who I'm afraid to play because I kinda suck at the more actiony bits of the game. How do I get offered three characters Like I was before?
29b Also How do I get offered the characters I want to play?
On december 30, 2014
Flash

A 29-29b:
When you click the play button on the main page your account is assigned to one of the ships that are trying to fill up (seems there are about 2 or some times 3 of these filling up at a time) and you will be given a limited list of characters that have not yet been picked on that ship. Since you only see Hua on that list it means that she's the last character that has not been picked. If you wait for someone else to pick Hua then you will be assigned to a new ship that is trying to fill up and you will be given a new list of characters to choose from. If none of those still don't suit you then wait a bit more for other people to pick them as this will give you new options if they are available.

On december 30, 2014
[6826491]

A30 addendum: The Derek Mush was indeed quarantined prior to selection, and showed up as a dead Mush in the Comrades Bar once selection occurred, however...it DID NOT qualify as having a dead Mush for the purposes of research.

For the purposes of The List, such a character would still be considered an Alpha at the moment of selection, even though they are already dead. As a result, it's a 50-50 chance that their name will be the guaranteed name to end up on The List, since it's guaranteed to have at least one Alpha.

It's almost never happened, and hasn't ever happened on this server (to my knowledge,) but if a ship reaches D4C1 and hasn't filled up yet, Mush selection happens with whoever is already aboard, and the game begins. In the absurdly unlikely event that only Chun and one other player are awake D4C1, then there can only be one possible Mush.

I strongly suspect that a person's human/Mush status is determined at the moment they wake up, based on this information. It probably has the same effect for the purposes of The List.
On december 30, 2014
Flash
SpazticusI strongly suspect that a person's human/Mush status is determined at the moment they wake up, based on this information. It probably has the same effect for the purposes of The List.

Yeah this is certainly possible but it could also be because the teams are assigned when all characters have been selected and the code just doesn't check for dead people before doing so.
On december 30, 2014
[6826491]
FlashYeah this is certainly possible but it could also be because the teams are assigned when all characters have been selected and the code just doesn't check for dead people before doing so.

That's quite possible, too; being dead doesn't influence The List regardless, since that would mean that you could literally eliminate your possible suspects in the first day or two, then have fewer names on it. Considering how utterly stupid that strategy would be for the human team, and the possibility that griefing might further ruin games, we're never going to subject this concept to testing. Besides, even if we did, there's no possible way for players to confirm how it all works.

DarkTheRaven

Just to elaborate on Impet's answer:

A logistics expert will give 1 ap to someone in the room other than themselves so in your situation

Paola > Stephen yes
Stephen > Paola yes
Paola > Paola no
Stephen > Stephen no
Paola > Others present in the room yes
Stephen > Others present in the room yes

Keep in mind that is who may get the ap, if all 16 crew are together odds are 1/15 you get it

Q39 How much control over membership does the Leader(s) of a casting have; are there any people within that casting who can remove members? Who has that control, just the original founder, or who else? What happens to a casting which has other members if the founder leaves?
On january 4, 2015
DarkTheRaven

A39 so to simplify this I'll break it down into numerous responses

A) The people who can remove members are the Director, should the director choose to allow it technically anyone could kick members, but unless the director changes the options the answer is only they can kick anyone it works a lot like twinoid groups

B) As stated the Director has the ability to choose who can and cannot kick, accept/deny and change the rank of members
A look at casting member options

Edit: Directors have all options shown enabled as well as some others that regard ship launching

C) there are 2 things that may happen if the creator leaves
Either he transfers ownership to another member Mush superiority had this happen between NERON and Aerial transferral does not force anyone out, just changes owners

Edit 2: The second director has all the rights of the first, the first loses all rights unless given to him by the current director

Or B the creator disbands the casting, anyone who funded the casting will have those tickets they spent returned and the casting will no longer exist

Q43. Will the human see if he is infected by a spore ?
On january 4, 2015
[6826491]

A43: There are circumstances in which it's possible: If they get spiked while under a camera, or if the action is revealed by an Observant Eleesha, then the action will be made public in the room logs.

If they scan themselves with the Mycoscan, then they'll know exactly how many spores they have at that moment. (Usually zero.)

Otherwise, they probably won't know for certain if they have any spores.

Online: 0-5 min after the action
Recently: 5 min - 3 hours

A long time ago: Any time beyond the above.

[8550239]

Depends on your strategy, if you wanna infect others i suggest splash proof and either save space for anonymush or take trapper
On january 6, 2015
DarkTheRaven

If you're a character like Raluca who's dirty alot and alone you can sometimes get off without splashproof, any sort of bridge crew needs splash proof if you plan to extract, same th researchers

Some of my favourite combos:
Splashproof/Trapper, if you trap the bays you can get pilots slowly but surely, note that trapper is a secret action so caution should be taken if you're close to anyone

Splashproof/Fungal kitchen, this is more of a long term strategy, you triple spore a ration and keep it in your inventory for a while, if you're forced to drop something try dropping your iTrackie as dropping it is undetectable and it cannot be stolen, eventually when the crew is desperate for food drop the ration someplace like the Icarus Bay nowhere with the microwave or the refectory hopefully they get desperate enough to eat uncooked and there's a new mush before dropping the iTrackie be sure to close any private tabs, otherwise it'll say you left your walkie talkie behind

Splashproof/Fertile, useful for characters with ap intensive jobs like Comms manager or Pilots, Fertile effectively allows you to bypass the constitaspore serum research meaning this combo is effective on active ships

Fertile/Infector, Despite the loss of showering ability this one can be a great infection play, as before Fertile allows you to bypass Constitaspore once a day and get 2 infections meaning with an active mush buddy d1 infections are possible

Trapper/Infector, Especially useful for getting pilots or Raluca, trap AB2 (the one with Pasiphae) then wait for it to be sprung by a pilot, head into AB2 and wait for them to land and spore them twice, there's another mush same tactic for Raluca but do it in engines

Note that most of these are random ship techniques, casting ships most likely won't fall for these too often

Oh and I nearly forgot my personal favorite:

Mycellium spirit/Infector Allowing the mush team to draw more spores and more infections, this combo is another great party pooper for the humans

On january 6, 2015
SummerMcLovin

A53: MycoAlarms work when placed in a shelf, even when they are hidden. When you are holding one, it will not ring. However, there will be a log of you picking it up (and if you had to search for a hidden one, they'll see the "found" log) which will be rather obvious. It won't ring retroactively or anything.

It will not ring if you extract a spore afterwards though, only when using them (or other Mush skills that they detect). If another person is in the room, it will be revealed as a red log though.

NGJon

Q85, some questions on vending machine food

A) can people tell you have bought it., or can they tell if you eat it that it is vending machine food?
B) if bought before mush selection and you become mush , do you keep it.
c) if you don't eat like a space potato or the thermos of coffee right away, will it spoil?
d) how can you share the thermos of coffee and can you drop a space potato for someone else to pick up?
e) if you do keep the items when you become mush, whats to stop mush from claiming they are confirmed human cos they have a therms of coffee?

A: If you purchase it with your inventory full, the item will appear on the shelf with the roomlog message that Name has knocked over Itemname. That is a way to offer proof to the ship that you purchased the item at that time. Otherwise there is no evidence for the crew that you purchased the item.

The eating message is the same as any other eating message, but sometimes you can tell it was vendor food eaten: If a character never had access to anything edible but eats, either you're wrong about access to edibles or that food came from the vending machine.

C: The thermos is like a portable and limited coffee machine: When used it creates a coffee and has 3 charges max. The coffee produced is always new, and will spoil like other foods after it is made. I'm not sure about the space potato, but if the object creates an edible instead of being eaten directly, spoiling should not occur.

D: Before purchase, you can see that some items are tradable and can be shared with the crew. If you want any ship item from the store to be available for others to use, hold items to fill your inventory before purchase so it appears on the shelf.

E: Mush can claim whatever they want. Humans can purchase Klix food at any point; mush cannot. I would accept roomlog proof (item knocked over) after mush selection as proof someone was not alpha mush (was not mush at the time they made that knocked over message). Knocking over a coffee from the thermos is not proof of anything but having the thermos.

Q90
when exploring a planet from a patrolship, and if you found oxygen
how does it work ?

oxygen is put in tanks as soon as explo finish ?
oxygen is put in tank when patrolship land ?
oxygen is droped in the bay when patrolship land ?

other ?
On january 13, 2015
[7950824]

A90: When the O2 is found, it is temporarily held on the ship that the expo was started from - either Icarus, or a patroller or the Pasiphae, whatever was used. Once the expo ends - if at least one player from that expo returns to the ship at the end of the expo - that O2 is instantly transferred to the Daedalus's O2 tanks.

If instead all of the expo team dies or gets lost, then the ship used to do the expo is lost forever, and the O2 (and fuel) it holds is also lost forever. Even if a member of the expo team lived as a missing person, and is found alive and brought back as a rescue - the ship from the first expo is lost forever, and any air or fuel it had, also lost.

Items found on expos are different - everything except O2 and fuel teleports to the bay the ship was launched from as soon as it is found. This actually allows another teammate on the Daedalus to go get an item found on expo and use it even before the ship returns from doing the expo.
On january 13, 2015
[6826491]
ImpetItems found on expos are different - everything except O2 and fuel teleports to the bay the ship was launched from as soon as it is found. This actually allows another teammate on the Daedalus to go get an item found on expo and use it even before the ship returns from doing the expo.

That used to be the case, but items are now supposed to only be deposited after the expo finishes successfully, just like O2 and fuel.1.82 Fix: The collection of objects from expeditions now happens at the end.

On january 13, 2015
[7950824]

O2 zones have about a 15% chance to fail to give O2.

If Hua is alive, and if Jin did an expo to the planet and came back sooner than the full expo time, then Hua is not lost (you can also verify this by looking at the alert bar, MIA teammates that are still alive and still lost show up there) - because finding lost teammates is part of the expo, but the expo is totally done if Jin came back early.

If Jin also did not find the O2 zone, then Hua had to have found it. If Hua has not landed yet, and is still in the fighter (you can see that from any turret, it shows the fighters in space and their pilots if any) then if O2 was gained it is on Hua's ship and the only way to get that O2 onto the Daedalus is for that ship to land.

If you have magnetic net, the ship will land automatically when the Daedalus moves. If you don't have magnetic net, then moving will lose that ship forever. If Hua is no longer in the fighter (if she ejected) then there is no way to get the O2 back that may be on that ship.

[7838255]

Q100 : how often i can print a list ? how many mush in there ? how may is the choices in there ?? In observant , having 25% seeing covert action , do I need to click something or how do I get the advantage of it ???

On january 16, 2015
[7950824]

A100 Once per ship, if you have the tracker skill and no one else on that ship has printed the tracker's list (normally only Eleesha has that skill or can get it).

There is guaranteed to be 1 alpha mush on the list - the presence of any other mush is incidental, and the alpha mush name you get is from before any transfers (so if they transferred, the person is probably human now), and could be a dead mush if you have a dead alpha.

The huge value to the list is that it cannot be printed unless there's currently at least one mush alive on the ship. Doesn't matter if the live mush is alpha or beta - if it is a mush that would show on the list for sure or not. But the tracker, if the list has never been printed, can see if the list could be printed - and that can be very useful.

Observant - it works automatically in two ways. The useful way - anyone doing a secret action in your room (like spiking you) has a 25% chance to be shown on the roomlog, like you were a camera.

The useless way - secret actions already on the log, like a camera catching someone eating - can be 'revealled' too, even though they are already revealed.

On january 21, 2015
[7950824]

A108 It's worth a 'working as intended' check, but it could be intended. The reason why it may be intended is a bit nebulous.

Pheromodem, pheromones. The mush channel works through smells, in a sense. Thus you can use mush channel while mutant, and you can use it with a torn tongue or burst eardrums (all those conditions render one unable to talk or hear; ability of both required in the game to speak or read messages - yet pheromodem works for those people if they have access to the channels), but there's a degree of 'cut off' from the ship's air supply where that fails. By that logic, an expo, especially one that requires spacesuits 'should' cut use of the mush channel as well, but doesn't. If possible grab a screenshot, Buzzard has asked us to include screenshots with all bug reports.

About patuline scrambler, right. It garbles readability, not access, to the mush channel. A fairly common (but false) belief among smarter new players is that you can 'mush test' by finishing patuline scrambler after pheromodem, then have each player speak in the channel, the players who fail to speak there are clearly mush - I've had at least 4 players explain this strategy to me on ships. Alas, it fails, because while the research description implies that is what happens, that 'mush are blocked from the channel', in reality everyone is affected and access is unchanged, just functionality.

1pringle

Q113: when the oxygen stocks on ship hit 0, what happens exactly? do all members just die, or is it 1 by 1 like some say?
On january 24, 2015
[7950824]

A113 It's 1 by 1, randomly chosen. And it happens right as O2 hits 0 - even if it is day change and plants are making more O2, the death will happen before O2 is added.

If the person randomly chosen has an O2 capsule in their inventory, instead of dying the player will be given a message in the roomlog about using the O2 capsule instead, and the capsule will be destroyed. If the player has multiple O2 capsules in hand, they are destroyed one at a time.

If the O2 tanks currently hold 1 O2 (or are broken and have 2, or if both broken, 3) then that last O2 will be lost, and a player will die at cycle change. So there's actually no benefit to leaving just 1 O2 in a tank, because the same result occurs as if the tank had 0 O2 - except if someone holds that O2, there is a chance that holder will be picked to die - instead of dying, the O2 is destroyed - no one dies that cycle.
On january 24, 2015

Skeksi

Q117: Can surgery cause loss of to the person being operated on, even if the surgery is a success?
On january 25, 2015
[7950824]

A 117: Sort of.

Most injuries cause your MAX health to lower. So if you normally can have up to 14 health, an injury might cause you to have at most 12 health. Lets say the player is at 12 health now, and cannot be healed.

Then surgery is done, and the injury is fixed - the player still has 12 health - but now their max health is 14. They can be healed. They did not really lose health, but they are now under maximum.

A120: Camera in Rear Corridor is useless. It prevent booby-traps and it looks like the only reason why the camera would put there. You might put it in one of bays, and in rear storage as well. Nexus is better place for camera. With secured Nexus people may meet in the Nexus to relay projects without the risk of being converted. Un-secured Nexus is not only a great seat for booby-traps, but even for direct spikes. To avoid convertion, people go to Nexus, relay projects and come back to dorms, wasting additional 4 MP for each relay instead of spending all 12 AP. With camera in the Nexus, projects go faster and relays are more efficient.

But chun sees her own ap, etc logs gain... okay, no wonder... explains a lot. thought system was glitchy or neron had bad memory or something. sorry so many questions, Q125: if a mush shelftraps a room, and I drop an item in the room, will I get the spore? on the other hand if I examine an item already in my inventory, would that trigger the spore?
On january 27, 2015
[6826491]

A125: No, in both cases. Dropping an item does not trigger the trap, nor does looking at the shelf. You can even attack someone in the room without triggering it. But interacting with a terminal, picking up an item from the shelf, and taking off with a patrol ship are some of ways to trigger a trap. It's the room's objects that are trapped, so to speak, but an item in your inventory is considered "still in your inventory." This is why Chun can safely "disarm" the trap in the room by dropping and picking up an item (or picking up and then dropping an item already in the room.) If a Mush does the same, the trap triggers and is wasted.
On january 27, 2015
[7950824]

A125 (Partial answer). Dropping an object in a room does not trigger a roomtrap. Nor does clicking the shelf to see what is there. Interacting with an object that is part of the room usually does - for example taking off in a fighter, or accessing a terminal. Interacting with the room itself also often sets off the roomtrap, example 'search'.

Amusingly, cooking a ration does not set off a roomtrap, and eating the cooked ration in that trapped room does not set it off either, however using the coffee machine will set off a roomtrap in the refectory.

Even more amusing - if a player dies picking up an object in a trapped room, the roomtrap is not triggered before the death happens and the spore will still be there for someone else to trigger.

I've not verified for myself yet if 'examine' sets off roomtraps.

Note about defacer and earlier roomlogs: I have seen several examples since the recent update, and in every case, defacer removed all previous logs. If it is now D5C2, and the room you just entered shows events for D5C2, D5C1, and D4C5, then the most recent the room could have been defaced is D4C4.
On january 27, 2015
sostin

How does work the castings? I see that to launch needs 24 players, so, there more that one character for ship? For example: two Janice's, Two Paola's, etc.
How does work the selection? Free to pick or defined for a lider? There a limit for each character? (Example: max 2 Jin Su.) In this case who makes this delimitation? Paper
On january 27, 2015
[7950824]

Castings launch sets of 16 players. If 32 players are 'ready', then two ships are launched. Each ship has its full set of 16 players, and each player is randomly assigned to a character. There is a max of one of each unique character per ship.

If there's more than 16 players, but less than 32, 16 are randomly selected from the ready group, and those not selected are not placed on a ship.

A130 The drone trick: To pick up more than one drone at once:

1) both drones need to be in the same room and not in inventory.
2) click on one of the drones and select 'pick up'.
3) wait for the game to do your action. Notice that you still have the drone selected, and still have the option to 'pick up'. Select 'pick up'.
4) If you make a mistake in this process, drop the drone you hold and start over. Clicking anything between the two 'pick up' selections will break the chain and you won't be able to pick up the second drone until you start over.
5) This process can work to carry three drones at once, just add a third 'wait for the game to process, then click 'pick up''.

On january 29, 2015
[7950824]

A134 follow up:


It does help. It just doesn't help in a way that makes it easy to detect.... it helps 'a little', still within the range of random chance, which is why every traitor mush is not shot the moment they return from expos.

See, it works like this. Lets say that there's a planet with 5 of all the same zone, nothing else.

Lets say this zone has these 4 chances:

A, the best possible result, 20% chance.
B, ok result, 40% chance
C, unpleasant result, 30% chance
D, really bad result, 10% chance.

That's the odds for each result, and every result is possible, every zone that's visited. A traitor free expo could get all the same results, good or bad - if you did 100 million expos to that exact set of zones, you'd find roughly 10 of them had gotten result D in all 5 zones.

The odds of any one expo getting 5 D results is about 1 in 10 million. But it does happen, and if 100 million expos were done, it would not be surprising to find that 10 of them had that result. 9 or 11 would not be surprising either. In fact, there's math that could tell you the odds of doing those 10 million expos and never once getting 5-D events on one at all. Now, to the team getting one of those all-D-result expos, wow, that was a shocker - but it's a 'why me' kind of event, not a 'wow, that was impossible'.

Because if you do enough expos, it is flat out a statistical guarantee that you will get that combo. And it could happen on the very first expo done, and could also happen on the second expo done (the odds of that are extremely small - but exist).




But lets talk about traitor. We are told that Traitor doubles the odds of getting bad events. Does that mean just the worst event? Does that mean that it exactly doubles the odds of the worst event, there was no mistranslation or 'fuzziness' about the meaning of the skill and the skill's actual function? The math is simpler if so, but as a mush I wouldn't be unhappy to see the team face increased chances to get 'bad, but not the worst possible' results.

There is a LOT here that is unclear. Even if it only doubles the chance to have the worst result, where did that percent change come from? spread evenly between the other possible events? Removed more from some than others? Taken straight away from the best possible outcomes?

That matters too, because if traitor doubles the bad result, our zone chances now look like this:

A, the best possible result, [less than or equal to] 20% chance.
B, ok result, [less than or equal to] 40% chance
C, unpleasant result, [less than or equal to] 30% chance
D, really bad result, 20% chance.

And, if we had 10 million expos done with a mush traitor, instead of expecting to see the worst result in all 5 zones about 1 time, we now expect to see it about 32 times. But you would have to do many hundreds of expos to be able to say with confidence 'the odds of getting zone D is about 20%, and the other zone chances have changed as well"

Since no one ship does hundreds of expos, I as mush feel pretty safe taking traitor and going on expos. It's going to make at least some of the better events less likely, and it's going to make at least one of the bad events more likely. That's in line with my desires as a mush - and unlike sabotage, spiking, rampaging, or most other mushy acts, I'm not actually doing anything that is clearly obvious. I'm not doing anything that would prove I was mush.

On january 31, 2015
[7950824]

A135 follow up:

There are two sorts of hunters, based on if your ship is moving when they arrive

1) Daedalus not moving: Brand new hunters, who must wait 1 cycle to fire at your ship, if they arrive C1 they will do no damage at the start of C2, but they will fire at the start of C3. If an asteroid is in this wave and you check the first cycle visible to you, you will see it needs 6 cycles to impact.

2) Daedalus is moving: These hunters apparently line up to shoot you as you stop moving, because they are ready to shoot at the next cycle change: If you move the ship C8, when you stop C1 and get hunters (you appear to always get hunters when you move), they are ready to fire at you C2. If an asteroid is in this wave and you check the first cycle visible to you, you will see it needs 5 cycles to impact.

Apparently, the cycle you move generates the hunters in your new location, but they are not revealed to you until the Daedalus stops moving. However they exist, and pass a cycle there, that being their 'can't fire' cycle - once you stop moving they are totally ready for you. That a 'brand new' asteroid seen when you stop moving has only 5 cycles to impact supports this theory.

[6826491]

A143: First off, the armor and Hardboiled skill together are bugged, and having both can leave you with no effect. As in, you have both, but neither triggers, and you can take full damage. never use both together, at least not until that bug is confirmed to be fixed.

Second, if you have the Natamy Rifle and Shooter points, your shots are free. Mush take 6-13 damage per hit from the Natamy Rifle, and that is not counting the fact that it can deal up to three injuries per hit. Two shots from that can easily kill a Mush, even if they're hiding behind Ian. You can even time it for the day change, so you take two or three shots a minute or so before the end of C8, and one to two more with the free shooter points gained at the cycle change.

A third option: Even if the Mush player is active, they have to sleep sometime. You can take that opportunity to shove them out of the room, and beat them unmercifully.

It's not an invincible combo; just difficult on the surface to deal with.

Q161 Does GPU absolutely works as advertised? I've heard a few weeks ago that it only postpones bad events, rather than actually remove them (in other words, the total day-load of hazards is spread over fewer cycles). Is that (still) correct?
On february 6, 2015
Aceb
zeebokQ161 Does GPU absolutely works as advertised? I've heard a few weeks ago that it only postpones bad events, rather than actually remove them (in other words, the total day-load of hazards is spread over fewer cycles). Is that (still) correct?

I had a ship where crew decided to go for GPU. It holded in total of 3 events in a row (15%? really?) and... BAM, we got 5 fires one cycle. It might be RNG but you know... many people says and seems to confirm it that GPU "stacks" bad events.
On february 6, 2015
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

Yes, it works as advertised. It prevents all events that were supposed to occur at cycle change, and does not delay them (if GPU works at cycle change, it means that one or severel event(s) were supposed to happen, it does not mean that those events will occur next cycle instead).

What is true is that the RNG determines what happens at cycle change based on what happened in the previous cycles. GPU may have an influence on that. But it's not proven either, because in order for GPU to work, the RNG has to decide first that something is going to happen, and only then does GPU have a chance to prevent it. There's no way to tell if, in the next cycles, the RNG will base the events on the events decided before or after GPU worked.

I'm not sure this is clear, so just an example : a fire is supposed to start on C2, and GPU prevents it. Does the RNG take that "ghost" fire into account when it decides what's going to happen on C3 ? Nobody knows that. The rumors are based on impressions and personal feelings, not on proofs.


AcebI had a ship where crew decided to go for GPU. It holded in total of 3 events in a row (15%? really?) and... BAM, we got 5 fires one cycle. It might be RNG but you know... many people says and seems to confirm it that GPU "stacks" bad events.

Remember that fires can either do damage or spread immediately to the adjoining rooms. Very often, when people are surprised because "we got 3 fires at the same time on D2, it's not normal", it was actually a single fire (which is normal) and it immediately spread twice. It wasn't 3 different fires.

This has already been done before for other parts of the game - witness the compilation of statistics on the frequency of each event result for expo zones on the wiki.

This is complicated slightly by the fact that bad events can occur in empty rooms - I've seen roomlogs of both roomshakes and electric spikes for corridor rooms without players in them - if no one had happened to walk through those rooms, we'd have never known they had a bad event because no players were affected - yet the bad events happened. Other bad events are targeted, like plates, or always announced, like fires.

Yet fires can spread multiple times - so fires are a poor indicator of the true number of genuine random events happening at cycle changes. I'm not sure any players have tried to compile, say, the odds of a fire spreading as the game cycles progress, but we do know that the difficulty increases over time and with AP spent.

Because of the huge number of factors that go into the equation before the RNG processes it further, to see what cycle change events happen each cycle, this data collection to be meaningful would need to be pretty complete and complex.

This is Mush. It's not answers spoonfed to us - would we really, really like it if it were?
On february 7, 2015
Aerial

It's pretty much impossible to prove or disprove it otherwise. There were tons of people who reported that GPU is bugged in the Bugs thread though, so there might be a correlation.

There were also tons of people who swore that post-its prevented fires, and there are tons of people who kill humans because "I've never seen such a bad expo, there was a traitor". And I could quote other "bugs" that were just people "feeling" that there was a problem.

The only things we know for sure are :
- The RNG bases its decisions on what happened in the previous cycles (among other things). That info is from the devs.
- But GPU only triggers if the RNG decides that something is going to happen. That's not from the devs, it's from observation on several long test ships.

So something does happen on GPU cycles, we just don't see those events. But the RNG had decided them. Either it bases the next cycles on those events (that would be logical), or it thinks that "nothing happened". There is no proof either way, and I doubt we get an answer from the devs, who are much less present on the forums now.

[8136654]

To clarify:
Q164: How much satisfaction does mush get from eating? Do they even have that stat?
On february 7, 2015
1412
nuctuTo clarify:
Q164: How much satisfaction does mush get from eating? Do they even have that stat?

A164: The answer is right above your post. And yes they have satisfaction.
On february 7, 2015
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

They do, even if it's invisible. They don't have a "positive" satisfaction : whatever they eat or drink (including pills, coffees and jumpkins, which give 0 satisfaction), they're full for 2 cycles. Maybe it does give them enough satisfaction to be full, but I don't know if that's how it works.

But their satisfaction decreases every cycle, just like the humans'. It starts decreasing from the start of the game and never stops decreasing until they eat. When they do, it resets their satisfaction to 0 and it starts decreasing again.

It has two consequences (well, three, but the third is so rare that it's not important, just a little funny) :
- If you cure a mush who has never eaten, they will be hungry and will start losing hp at the next cycle change.
- If a mush who has never eaten transfers, their old character will be hungry too.
- If the overall satisfaction of the crew is too low, there's a "Famine" alert in the status bar. But it has to be very low, which means that it almost never happens except on long coop ships. In other words, Neron thinks that the crew is starving because it considers that the mush are "hungry", even if the humans keep eating and have plenty of food.

Flash

A 168:
I believe it'll still let you use it again even though a fix was implemented some time ago that prevented people from getting more drones or hydropots the same way.

A 169:
It's the general time since a person took an action or talked in private chat. Talking in general or Mush chat does not update it. This is what I believe the times mean:
Online: 0 seconds - 3 minutes
Recently: 3 min - 3 hours
A moment ago: 3 hrs - 6 hrs
A long time ago: 6+ hrs

I could be wrong so feel free to test it yourself.

A185 No, so you can drink any amount of coffee in a row (if human), however....


Coffee will prevent starvation.

Satiation can be 'negative', sort of. After your satiation reaches 0, you have 24 cycles before you start to starve.

If your satiation was 0 and you drink coffee, it 'takes your satiation to 0' again - you gain another 24 cycles before you will start to starve, and this keeps resetting with every new coffee.

On february 19, 2015
sperbi

A120 (or 192 because NERON can't count ):

At least from my experience it would fix an equipment first before taking off. Fixing stuff seems always to be the priority unless there is a fire.
A firefighter drone should extinguish the fire first.

BUT!
Actually a drone is only doing their job before recognizing what new events happened around cycle change.
So if a drone is in a room and fixing stuff, then a fire does appear at cycle change, it will proceed to fix stuff, but extinguish the fire not before the following cycle. And if a drone is in a room with nothing to do, then at cycle change there is a fire appearing or something is breaking down, it will still leave the room.
There is still one exception. When a turbo drone is leaving a previously fine room where something new happened at cycle change (or not, doesn't make difference) and is coming to another room where something new happened at cycle change, THEN it will repair/extinguish the new appeared things in the second room.
On february 19, 2015
sperbi

...follow-up: keeping that in mind it can even explain how DTR saw one time a drone taking off while broken patrol craft was in bay-that woudl happen if the pilot drone was already in bay before cycle change and at cycle change the patrol craft got broken, the drone didn't realised that yet and did take off since there were hunters outside.

Theoretically (haven't tried that yet) a pilot drone shouldn't even take off at the same cycle when being in a bay and there is a new hunter wave appearing (and previously there were no hunters). Unless it moved at cycle change to the bay and has another free action because of turbo.

Q : List will show only name of a mush or it can show two?
On february 22, 2015
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mÃ©chant ?

It always shows the list of an alpha mush (it doesn't take transfers and beta mush into account). Then it picks 7 other names at random, which can include the other mush or Chun.
On february 22, 2015
[6826491]
SorooshQ204: List will show only name of a mush or it can show two?

A204: It CAN show two the names of two Mush, but is only guaranteed to show one Alpha. The name(s) it shows only apply to the moment of Mush selection. It does not account for Transfers or conversions, and the guaranteed Mush on the list could be someone who is already dead by the time the list is printed.

That said, the best use for the list is when it can't be printed at all, because that moment is when you are confirmed to be Mush-free. It is still possible for conversions to happen after that point, though...

On february 26, 2015
Aceb

Q209: If both o2 tanks are destroyed, does ship loses 3x o2 per cycle or still 2x o2?
Q209a: If one/both tanks are destroyed, does it make 1/2 more people death due to lack of oxygen if there's no oxygen left? (0x o2 at cycle change)
On february 26, 2015
Aerial
AcebQ209: If both o2 tanks are destroyed, does ship loses 3x o2 per cycle or still 2x o2?
Q209a: If one/both tanks are destroyed, does it make 1/2 more people death due to lack of oxygen if there's no oxygen left? (0x o2 at cycle change)

A209: If both o2 tanks are broken, the ship loses 3x o2 per cycle.

A209a: Only 1 person dies of asphyxiation at cycle change, no matter how many oxygen tanks are broken.
On february 26, 2015
[7950824]

A209 follow up: if O2 canisters are in the inventory of the player selected to die, instead of dying one of the carried O2 canisters will be destroyed and the player will receive a secret message about using that O2 to survive.

Additionally, the death from 'no O2' happens the cycle that 0 O2 is reached - so if you have no broken O2 tanks, but have 1 O2 left, there will be a death at cycle change - having that 1 O2 that is consumed in the tank at cycle change does not prevent a player's death, so if you have 1 O2 left, there's actually no survival benefit for anyone to just leave that in the tank to be wasted. Even if it's day change and the plants will be making more O2 at the changeover, if the O2 tank hits 0, a death will happen.

If there are enough broken tanks to take the O2 to 0, a death will occur at cycle change, so the lowest survivable O2 with 1 broken tank is 3 O2 at cycle change, the lowest survivable O2 with 2 broken tanks is 4 O2 at cycle change.

Wiki:

Installing and removing cameras is secret for you.

My account tool tip:

With a little bit of help from your rhizomes, you can do some wonderful things. Manipulating cameras for example....
Your build and dismantle actions are covert.

Now, cameras are not the only thing that gets built and dismantled. Blueprints also are built (Doing so it already a private action, so this skill wouldn't improve it, hopefully doesn't mess it up), and all sorts of objects can be dismantled. Dismantle is normally a public action.

PanatWhy ppl always install 3rd camera (Gio doesnt pick paranoid) on bridge. Why not lab ???

I think it's one of those things that started to be done and people just got used to it.

I remember some discussion about this bridge/laboratory camera thing sevaral months ago. Basically, the result was a draw, if I'm not mistaken. There were lots of reasons to have camera on bridge and lots of reasons for camera in laboratory. It ended by stating that in the end, it depends on particular ship's situation. That ships are better suited for camera on bridge, others for camera in laboratory. But for some reason "camera on bridge" is something what is still taken as no-brainer on most ships.

If I remember correctly, on French server it's the other way around and people are expected to install third camera in laboratory without any discussion.

So, if you want third camera in laboratory, feel free to discuss it with your crewmates. With good reasons for that, there's no "rule" to not have it there.
